me.sudofu.sanitycheck
[Groovy] Class StringCoerciveSanityChecker

java.lang.Object
  me.sudofu.sanitycheck.SanityChecker
      me.sudofu.sanitycheck.StringCoerciveSanityChecker

class StringCoerciveSanityChecker
extends SanityChecker

An implementation of SanityChecker which provides mnemonics for sanity-checking entities and coercing them if possible.

The StringCoerciveSanityChecker is designed to not only provide sanity checks, but also coerce String objects into the mnemonic datatype being checked for.

This has the distinct advantage of being used in places where data might be normalized, or even allows for that normalization to occur. For example, a REST resource that operates on JSON. Or, for sanity-checking Groovy Named-Parameter method signatures. The very best use-case for this checker is when working with a Map, since all methods return the entity that is being checked: pass or fail, coerced or not.

An example of use: 

 Map normalizedInput = [
     name: "John Doe",
     age: "42",
     height: '172.72',
 ]

 SanityChecker checker = new StringCoerciveSanityChecker()

 normalizedInput.with {
     checker.runChecks {

         check('name', name)
         isString()
         isNotEmpty()

         age = check('age', age).isInteger()

         height = check('height', height).isDouble()

         maxLong = check('maxLong', maxLong).isInteger()
     }
 }

Note that the behavior of coercion is based on Groovy buil-ins. Therefore, should Groovy alter the behavior of its coercion, that will also alter the behavior of this checker.

Authors:
Aaron Brown

Constructor Detail

StringCoerciveSanityChecker

StringCoerciveSanityChecker()
Constructs a StringCoerciveSanityChecker which disallows null to pass sanity checks.

StringCoerciveSanityChecker

StringCoerciveSanityChecker(boolean allowPassOnNull)
Constructs a StringCoerciveSanityChecker, specifying the allowance of null passing sanity cheks.

There are two distinct behaviors of a SanityChecker:

  1. Implicitly check for null, and disallow nulls to pass the sanity check.
  2. Implicitly check for null, and allow nulls to pass the sanity check.

 
Method Detail

entityIsCoercible

protected boolean entityIsCoercible()
Detect coercible entities.
Returns:
true if the entity is coercible, false otherwise.

isBigDecimal

java.lang.Object isBigDecimal()
Run a sanity check to ensure the entity is a(n) BigDecimal.

Default behavior specified by allowPassOnNull

throws:
IllegalStateException An entity must be declared via a check() invokation before any sanity checks can be performed.
Returns:
The entity that was checked; or, if a String and coercible to BigDecimal, then the BigDecimal.
